gain.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to obtain or achieve something you want or need
gain.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: After gaining independence in 1957, it was renamed ‘Ghana’.
Radical left-wing parties gained control of local authorities.
He gained a doctorate in Chemical Engineering.
gain.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually say get rather than gain:
She got a degree in English.
gain.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to gradually get more and more of a quality, feeling etc, especially a useful or valuable one
gain.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She has gained a reputation as a good communicator.
Many of his ideas have gained popular support.
an opportunity to gain experience in a work environment
The youngsters gradually gain confidence in their abilities.
The sport has gained in popularity in recent years.
gain.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to get an advantage from a situation, opportunity, or event
gain.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: an attempt to gain a competitive advantage over their rivals
Who really stands to gain (=is likely to get an advantage) from these tax cuts?
There’s nothing to be gained (=it will not help you) by losing your temper.
There is much to be gained from seeking expert advice early.
gain.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to increase in weight, speed, height, or value
gain.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Carrie’s gained a lot of weight recently.
The dollar has gained 8% against the yen.
gain.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a clock or watch gains, or if it gains time, it goes too fast
gain.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to reach a place after a lot of effort or difficulty
gain.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The swimmer finally gained the river bank.
gain.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: gain control
The government of mainland China gained control of the island in 1683.
gain power
Many women wanted to gain power in a male-dominated world.
gain independence
Jamaica has had this flag since 1962, when it gained independence from Britain.
gain a reputation
He had gained a reputation as a crook.
gain notoriety
He gained notoriety as the author of a controversial novel.
gain support
The proposal failed to gain support.
gain popularity
Governments gain popularity by cutting taxes.
gain acceptance
The theory has gradually gained acceptance among scientists.
gain credibility
Screen actors feel that they gain credibility when they perform on stage.
gain experience
In her first job, she gained experience as a programme manager.
gain knowledge
Knowledge gained from the research will be used directly to help patients.
gain confidence
The managers were gaining confidence in their ability to take calculated risks.
gain strength
He is beginning to gain strength again after his illness.
gain an understanding
Drama is one of the key ways in which children can gain an understanding of themselves and of others.
gain an insight (into something)
You can gain an insight into horses’ feelings by the physical signs they give out.
gain momentum
In the 1850s and 1860s, the British colonisation of India gained momentum.
quickly/rapidly gain something
Adam quickly gained the respect of the soldiers under his command.
steadily gain something
The king was steadily gaining more support.
gradually gain something
He is gradually gaining confidence in his own abilities.
gain.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an advantage or improvement, especially one achieved by planning or effort
gain.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The party made considerable gains at local elections.
the potential gains from improved marketing
There are obvious gains for the student.
gain.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an increase in the amount or level of something
gain.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The Democratic Party needed a net gain of only 20 votes.
Eating too many fatty foods could cause weight gain.
Retail sales showed a gain of 0.4%.
gain.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: financial profit, especially when this seems to be the only thing someone is interested in
gain.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: They are seeking to realize the maximum financial gain.
Such research should not be for personal gain.
gain.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to get or achieve something important or valuable, usually by working very hard
gain.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: We hope togain a largershare of the local market.
BP America shared the knowledge gained from the disaster with other oil companies.
gain.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to gradually get more of a useful or valuable quality, skill etc
gain.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Donald gained a lot of usefulexperience when he was working for a merchant bank.
Employees will gain in knowledge and confidence by making full use of the training opportunities.
gain.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to increase in value or amount
gain.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index gained slightly, closing up 3.75 points.
Production in both China and India gained while domestic consumption slowed.
For the week, the Dow industrials gained 39.85 points.
gain.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: if a currency, share, or financial market gains ground, it increases in value
gain.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The stock market gained ground after two days of losses.
The dollar gained ground against  (=compared to) foreign currencies.
gain.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: to gradually become more popular, successful etc
gain.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: The retailer has gained ground, with sales up 12.2%.
Aluminium has been gaining ground against  (=compared to) more traditional metals.
GM’s trucks are gaining ground on Ford’s F series.
gain.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: to get an advantage from a situation, opportunity, or event
gain.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: Some countries depreciated their currencies so as to gain a competitive advantage over their trading rivals.
Malaysia has not always gained greatly from the sales of assets such as shares in its airline.
People with higher incomes clearly gained more from the tax cuts.
The management group owns about 18% of the stock and would stand to gain millions of dollars if the company were sold.
gain.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: to reach a position from which you can start to make progress and achieve your aims
gain.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: European television groups will be ready to pay substantial amounts to gain a foothold in the UK market.
gain.translation[2].definitions[7].examp: The new idea was gaining currency.
gain.translation[2].definitions[8].defin: if a country or company gains access to a place, it is able to sell its products there for the first time
gain.translation[2].definitions[8].examp: The government’s aim is to help US companies gain access to foreign markets.
US computer makers have accused the Japanese of selling machines at steep discounts to gain access to markets where they are not competitive.
gain.translation[2].definitions[9].defin: to manage to use something, especially something that is difficult to obtain
gain.translation[2].definitions[9].examp: The program allows a hacker to secretly gain access to computer systems.
gain.translation[2].definitions[10].defi: if a plan, proposal etc gains approval, it is officially accepted
gain.translation[2].definitions[10].exam: The company did not gain approval from the planning commission for the new building.
gain.translation[2].definitions[11].exam: Insurance-funded plans are gaining in popularity because they are not subject to tax.

The senator denied the charge that he was using his office for personal gain.
gain.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: The new machinery has produced bigefficiency gains.
gain.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: money or an advantage obtained dishonestly
gain.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: The police now have been given more powers to crack down on drug dealers and seize their ill-gotten gains.
